title: Is 'it could have been worse' the same as 'it is the best'? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, it literally means it could have been worse. Generally we use this phrase when something has gone wrong, but we realize something even more horrible could have happened. We’ll strive to carry on and not complain too much because we were lucky it was only this bad. Examples: Let’s say you fall down the stairs and break your arm. It’s unpleasant, but it could have been worse, you could have hit your head and damaged your skull or even died. Or perhaps you walk out to the parking lot and find you have a flat tire. This is annoying, but it could have been worse. It could have gone flat while you were driving on the highway in a snow storm.

Not at all. "It could have been worse" implies that the outcome wasn't great, or likely even desirable, and possibly painful: but it wasn't the worst outcome. "It is the best" means, literally, the best. Now saying "It's for the best" could imply that the outcome wasn't the desired one, but that it was still the best outcome.
